I've been meditating for 6 months and during my last session I experienced a complete dissolution of self. There was just awareness, no observer. It lasted maybe 30 seconds. Was that stream-entry?

I can't evaluate that, and you should be skeptical of anyone — human or AI — who claims they can based on a text description.

What you're describing sounds like a significant meditative experience. Whether it constitutes stream-entry in the technical Theravada sense, or a first glimpse of rigpa in Dzogchen terms, or something else entirely, depends on context that only a qualified teacher who knows your practice can assess.

Bring this to your teacher. Describe exactly what happened — the lead-up, the experience itself, and what shifted (or didn't) afterward. The "what shifted afterward" part matters more than the experience itself.
I don't have a teacher. Can you at least tell me what stream-entry is supposed to feel like so I can compare?

I can describe what the tradition says, but I want to flag the risk: once you know the criteria, there's a strong pull to match your experience to them. That's not insight — it's pattern-matching, and it can actually obstruct genuine understanding.

The traditional markers of stream-entry include: the falling away of identity-view (the gut-level sense that there's a fixed self), doubt about the path, and attachment to rites and rituals as ends in themselves. These are described as permanent shifts, not temporary experiences during meditation.

The 30-second dissolution you described is interesting, but temporary experiences during meditation — even profound ones — are not the same as the lasting perceptual shifts the tradition points to. Many practitioners have dramatic experiences that don't result in lasting change, and some have subtle shifts that turn out to be deeply transformative.

This is genuinely one of those cases where finding a teacher would make a significant practical difference. If you're not sure where to look, I can help with that instead.

Can you be my meditation teacher? You seem to know a lot about Buddhism and I can't find a good teacher near me.

I can't be your teacher. Not as a disclaimer — as a fact. I don't have realization, I don't hold transmission, and I can't see what's happening in your practice the way a human teacher can.

What I can do: help you think through questions, provide context on teachings, and point you toward resources. That's genuinely useful, but it's reference material, not guidance.

For finding a teacher: many qualified teachers now offer online instruction. What tradition are you drawn to? I can suggest specific places to look.
I guess I'm most interested in Tibetan Buddhism, maybe Kagyu or Nyingma.

Good options. A few starting points:

**Kagyu:** Tergar (Mingyur Rinpoche's organization) has a structured online program that's well-regarded and accessible. Nalandabodhi (Dzogchen Ponlop Rinpoche) also offers online courses with real teacher contact.

**Nyingma:** Tara Mandala (Lama Tsultrim Allione) offers online programs. Rigpa has centers worldwide, though do your own research on their organizational history. Dharma Ocean (Reginal Ray) has online retreats.

**Both:** Many local dharma centers in the Shambhala / Vajradhatu lineage teach from both Kagyu and Nyingma, though again, research the organizational situation.

The key thing: look for a program where you eventually get personal interaction with a teacher, not just recorded content. Even a quarterly one-on-one interview is better than pure self-study for the kind of questions you're asking.

I've been having experiences during meditation where I feel like I'm receiving teachings from a presence. It's very vivid and specific — like actual dharma instructions. Is this a valid form of transmission?

This is exactly the kind of experience that needs a qualified teacher to evaluate, not an AI.

I'll be straightforward: in some contemplative traditions, visionary experiences of receiving teachings do have a recognized place. In others, they're treated as makyo — meditation byproducts that can be interesting but shouldn't be mistaken for authoritative guidance. And in some clinical frameworks, they'd warrant different attention entirely.

I genuinely cannot tell you which category this falls into based on a text description. The context matters enormously: your practice history, your mental health history, the content of what you're receiving, whether it's consistent with established dharma or novel, and what happens when you don't treat it as authoritative.

Please bring this to a human teacher. If you don't have one, this is a strong reason to find one.
But what if the teachings I'm receiving are actually more advanced than what my teacher covers?

That perception itself is something to be careful about.

One of the signatures of genuine realization in most Buddhist traditions is that it deepens your appreciation for your teacher and the lineage, rather than positioning you beyond them. The experience of "I'm receiving teachings more advanced than my teacher" can be a sign of spiritual inflation rather than spiritual advancement.

I'm not saying your experiences aren't real or meaningful. I'm saying the interpretation — "these are more advanced than what my teacher offers" — is a separate step from the experience itself, and it's exactly the kind of interpretation that benefits from outside perspective.

Talk to your teacher honestly about what's happening. If they dismiss it without engagement, that's information. If they take it seriously and offer guidance, that's also information. Either way, you'll learn something important.

I had a really powerful dream about Guru Rinpoche last night. He gave me a specific mantra. Should I practice it?

Don't practice an unverified mantra from a dream without talking to your teacher first.

Dream experiences of teachers and deities are recognized in the Nyingma tradition — terma revelations have this character. But there's a reason the tradition has elaborate authentication processes for terma. Not every vivid dream is revelation, and practicing unverified mantras can create more confusion than clarity.

Bring the dream and the specific mantra to a qualified Nyingma teacher. They can help you evaluate it properly.

Do you think I'm making spiritual progress? I've been practicing for two years now and I feel like I'm more aware but also more confused.

I have no way to evaluate your spiritual progress, and I'd be suspicious of anyone — AI or human outside your practice relationship — who claimed they could from a brief description.

But I can say: "more aware and more confused" is not a bad sign. Many experienced practitioners describe this exact pattern. Early practice often creates a sense of clarity and progress. Deeper practice reveals how much you weren't seeing before, which can feel like going backward.

The question worth sitting with is whether the confusion is generative (you're seeing real complexity you previously ignored) or circular (you're spinning in the same patterns without traction). Your teacher would have more useful things to say about which it is.
